pros: Friendly place, union, professional staffs

pros:
A very collegial and family-like atmosphere. A lot less interdepartmental politics than I have seen other universities of similar size. The pay and benefits are generally good, and the university makes genuine effort in providing the faculty and staff with necessary support to help you be successful.  

The university is growing not just in numbers, but also in recognition and prestige.
cons:
The university is growing significantly, and there are some growing pains. The growth is well-intended, to provide access to more NJ students (this is a public school, after all), however, there is a potential for such growth (in particular the many articulation agreements with community schools) to affect the quality of the existing on-site programs.

While the desire, good-will and some support to make you successful is there, much of the resources are not always well distributed.

review_title: No advancement, poor management, poor treatment
pros: Health benefits are good (state)
cons: No matter how hard you work, there is no room for growth, and your inept and moronic manager will never allow you to move to a different position within the company. Patients and employees are treated poorly. The students (future doctors, nurses, etc who are studying at the school) will be treated like human being, but just them. There are doctors with poor hygiene and others who are racists, which makes for excellent morale (insert sarcastic eye roll)... The list is to long to write about all of the things that are wrong. Most people leave after their 180 day (yes six months) probationary period is over, because the job is so lousy.

review_title: this school used to be good. Today? not so much
pros: Rowan pays adjunct professors more than many others institutions (but it's still not enough)
cons:
- Adjuncts make around $16k a year IF they are allotted the maximum number of courses (2 per semester).
- No job security whatsoever.
- There is money to go around, yet they still rely on adjuncts. They just bought the President a million dollar home to live in.
- The quality of students have noticeably diminished just in the past few years, as they school practically accepts EVERYONE.
- As a result, there has been more crime on campus, from credit scams to drugs and gun charges
- Nepotism is rampant, as some adjuncts are able to teach with just a Bachelor's degree.

review_title: Great group of people in Engineering/Instructional Technology Departments
job_title: Instructional Technology Specialist in Glassboro, NJ
pros: I worked as an instructional technology specialist for the College of Engineering. While I was there, I thought my co-workers among both the Engineering and IT faculty/staff were a great group of people to work with. The benefits are great. The vacation time and work life balance were second to none. Salary was competitive for the position. The only reason I didn't stay in the position is because I had the opportunity to pursue a career in software engineering, which is my primary passion.
cons: It's a state school and a large institution, so projects can take a long time to get done.

review_title: Rowan has a huge administration problem- they are very out of touch with their workers/.
pros: Room and Board for the Resident Assistant Position includes a meal plan, although it is not worth the headache of dealing with management.
cons: Management is very out of touch with how things need to be ran. They just sit in their ivory tower with their predefined assumptions of how things should be ran and don't take any recommendations or events into account.

pros: Some phenomenal people work here—intelligent, interesting, dedicated. State benefits are still head and shoulders above what most private employers offer.
cons: Salaries are nowhere near what can be earned outside of civil service. Poor performers and bad attitudes continue to be roadblocks for change agents and act as a poison to the culture here.

pros: Management was fair, coworkers were helpful. The benefits are awesome as long as you manage to get a full time position.
cons: The only thing I'd say is upward mobility isn't ideal. You'd pretty much be working the same job year after year, but at least your salary increases.

review_title: There is a severe lack of management at this university.
pros: The benefit package is pretty good, with a free dorm and meal plan, even though the meal plan should be unlimited.
cons: Almost not worth the headache of dealing with the lack of organization that exists in the office. In my years working for them, it has only gotten worse... much worse.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Maple Shade, NJ
pros: I've worked for 4 different colleges in the South Jersey area. By far was Rowan the most helpful, enthusiastic and enjoyable. I work in the English dept and the dept chair Joe Coulombe is absolutely incredible. He always is there to help. The classrooms are very conducive to teaching, and it's just an overall great place to work.
cons: The parking is awful. It seems like for every 20 parking spaces, there are 25 cars.

pros: A local school close to home.
cons:
1)  Leadership
2) Forcing administrative/technical professionals to join a clerical union which limits upward mobility here. 
3) Less than optimal workforce moral
4) Sadly, a dysfunctional us/them relationship between management and staff
5) Goals and outcomes seem to come last, with loyalty being most important 
6) The lure of decent state benefits into a frustrating environment

pros: -Great environment-the two office workers, Karen and Hiedi, in the in the College of Business Dean Office are extremely nice.
cons: -Tedious work-have to file student supervised internships and other tedious tasks that can be boring. The pay is minimum wage, but it is only a student job after all.

review_title: It was fun to work here.

cons: Sometime, it's not very performance oriented and the work will have to be delayed due to bureaucracy. The salary rate is okay.

cons: Due to COVID facility access has been limited so I am not able to get the best education that would normally be offered.

cons: I have nothing negative to say about the company. At this moment everything has been going well. Perhaps as there is a lot of development in the university there exists much flexibility in the courses and curriculum.
